original_title: Sri Lanka deflation not harmful, economy growing: CB Governor
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s current deflation is not harmful to the economy and is a correction from previous very high inflation, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.
The deflation is reducing the cost of living for the people and also the cost of production of companies, he said.
“It comes after very high inflation,” Governor Weerasinghe told reporters Wednesday after reducing its policy rate to 8.0 percent from an earlier corridor of 9.25 to 8.25 percent.
“We had food inflation of 100 percent. We see the deflation as a correction.”
Sri Lanka’s economy has been recovering and the economy is growing around 4.5 percent amid the price falls, Governor Weerasinghe said.
“If there is some negative effect from deflation, it has to be shown through economic growth. So we see it as as correction.
“It is good for the cost of living. So it is a benefit for the people.
Sri Lanka’s deflation is expected to continue in the near term, he said.

Until World War I and the invention of the policy rate (printing money to control interest rates without a war) in the 1920s there was no permanent inflation in the world and exchange rates were fixed to each other.
Under the classical gold standard all productivity gains from free enterprise went to the people.

Joseph Salerno, a classical economist, estimated that from 1880 to 1896, wholesale prices fell 30 percent in the US under the classical specie standard or around 1.75 percent a year, and real incomes rose 85 percent a year.
Early in the next century factory workers stared to buy cars Model T Ford being mass produced from 1908. The price of the Model T fell around 900 to below 300 dollars by the mid 1920s.
The US did not have Fed at the time and the Bank of England was denied ‘instrument independence’ by the British parliament through several laws. The Fed was set up in 1916.

It invented open market operations in the 1920s, printed money without a war, amid budget surpluses and triggered an economic bubble which ended in the Great Depression, leading to current beliefs of inflation among the academic community and the birth of what some classicals call the ‘age of inflation’.
During the Great Moderation from 1980 to 2000 under Volcker and Bernanke, gold prices fell around 800 to 284 dollars.

The Fed then started to ‘reflate’ the economy mis-interpreting a productivity driven price falls as a depression style collapse, according to critics under the tutelage of Ben Bernanke (as vice chair at the time) triggering the housing bubble and the Great Recession.  (Colombo/Nov27/2024)
